post_text:
Juniors-Only PSAT - October 14

On Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2020, Cheltenham High School is hosting a no-cost, juniors-only Preliminary SAT/National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test, a practice test for the SAT exam. If students earn a high score, they could qualify for National Merit Scholarships. Practice test>>> http://ow.ly/GAEP50BsSdW

Students should register online by Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2020. Transportation will be provided to and from the high school. Additional information will be provided in the next few weeks.
Register>>>http://ow.ly/v3oU50BsSh7

If you have any questions, contact CHS Vice Principal Lori Felgoise at lfelgoise@cheltenham.org .

post_text:
"SO NOW WHAT?" WEBINAR SERIES FROM THE Allegheny Intermediate Unit

HELPING PARENTS & CAREGIVERS NAVIGATE A SCHOOL YEAR LIKE NO OTHER

Three webinars remaining! Register today.

Families are in the middle of what is already an unprecedented start to the school year, not to mention all we experienced this past spring. Youâ€™re processing lessons already learned, adjusting to new ways of preparing your kids and often figuring it out for yourselves. A lot of us are asking...So Now What?

The So Now What? virtual series brings the countryâ€™s leading experts in education and childhood development, including PBS Kids, Common Sense Media, Learning Heroes and UPMC Childrenâ€™s Hospital, together with parents and caregivers to share and learn from one another. We will cover a range of topics specific to this moment in time, including social emotional wellness, mental health, learning resources, communication, tech safety and much more.

Together we will navigate the start to this new, uncharted school year, and make plans for what comes next, no matter what tomorrow brings.

post_text:
CSD is distributing lunches for September 8 - 11 to its students tomorrow, Wednesday, Sept. 2. K-8 students can pick up at Cedarbrook from 10 a.m. - noon, and high schoolers can pick up at CHS between 10 a.m. - noon. To accommodate more families, the district is offering K-12 students pick up at Cedarbrook from 5 - 6 p.m.

Students pay according to their eligibility status (free, reduced or paid). Reduced lunch is $.40; and full price is $2.85 (K-6) and $3.25 (7-12). Free/reduced lunch applications and eligibility letters have been distributed in back-to-school packets. Until a familyâ€™s eligibility for this year is determined, eligibility will default to this past yearâ€™s classification. Payments will be accepted online via schoolcafe.com (login required) or check during lunch pick up. Cash will not be accepted. As a reminder to our families, please make sure you are maintaining a positive balance in your child(ren)â€™s lunch account(s).
text:
CSD is distributing lunches for September 8 - 11 to its students tomorrow, Wednesday, Sept. 2. K-8 students can pick up at Cedarbrook from 10 a.m. - noon, and high schoolers can pick up at CHS between 10 a.m. - noon. To accommodate more families, the district is offering K-12 students pick up at Cedarbrook from 5 - 6 p.m.

Students pay according to their eligibility status (free, reduced or paid). Reduced lunch is $.40; and full price is $2.85 (K-6) and $3.25 (7-12). Free/reduced lunch applications and eligibility letters have been distributed in back-to-school packets. Until a familyâ€™s eligibility for this year is determined, eligibility will default to this past yearâ€™s classification. Payments will be accepted online via schoolcafe.com (login required) or check during lunch pick up. Cash will not be accepted. As a reminder to our families, please make sure you are maintaining a positive balance in your child(ren)â€™s lunch account(s).

post_text:
Cheltenham School District Welcomes Shannon Gelnett

I grew up nearby in Upper Moreland Township. I attended Penn State University for my undergraduate degree in early childhood and adolescent education. For the first five years of my career, I taught third grade in North Central Pennsylvania, while also completing my master's degree in instructional media with a PA STEM endorsement. I'm thrilled to be back in third grade locally with the wonderful teaching team at Cheltenham!

#CSDimpact #BacktoCSD #ThisIsCheltenham #ThisIsCES

post_text:
Cheltenham School District Welcomes Claire Schneider

I am thrilled to be returning to Cheltenham High School as a long-term substitute working with the CHS vocal arts department as director of choirs and teaching beginning guitar and digital music production. I served as a long-term substitute teaching vocal music at Cedarbrook Middle School for spring of 2020. During fall of 2019, I completed my student teaching placement with Jenny Hutton and CHS Vocal Arts. I graduated from Temple University's Boyer College of Music and Dance with a Bachelor of Music degree in music education and certification of specialization in Spanish.

#CSDimpact #BacktoCSD #ThisIsCheltenham #PantherPride

Cheltenham School District Welcomes Keely Clauson

I am an early childhood and elementary certified teacher and a graduate of Arcadia University. I am also in graduate school and working towards obtaining my master's degree in reading and ESL. The 2020-2021 school year will be my 19th year teaching children and my second year teaching in Cheltenham. I look forward to taking on the challenge of teaching virtually. It will be an experience that none of us will forget!

post_text:
The district is providing drive by lunch pick up for its students for the first week of school today at CSD Cheltenham High School and CSD Cedarbrook Middle School. Follow the signs!

K-8 families can pick up at Cedarbrook from 10 a.m. - noon .

High school families/students can pick up at CHS from 10 a.m. - noon .

To accommodate more families, the district is offering K-12 students pick up at Cedarbrook from 5 - 6 p.m.

Following this initial event, distribution will be on Wednesdays at the same times and locations until further notice.

For more details, visit cheltenham.org/road2reopening.

#DidYOUKnow the CSD Road2Reopening hub at cheltenham.org/road2reopening contains helpful technology resources and tutorials for families and students?

Visit the technology page at http://ow.ly/K6z750B9Ovw to find a Family Ambassador Support Team (FAST) guidebook for getting started with Google apps, tutorial directory with links for app-specific tasks, guide for creating and using the Canvas parent/guardian portal, as well as other important CSD-specific technology support resources.

Special thanks to the CSD Department of Innovation for curating these helpful tools.

Cheltenham School District Welcomes Maddy Parkes

I am so excited to be the new vocal music teacher at Cedarbrook Middle School! I grew up in Langhorne, Pennsylvania, and went to Ithaca College, where I graduated with a double major in music education and piano performance. Besides being a choir nerd, I am passionate about connecting music to students' personal lives and to the world around them, all while creating quality musical experiences and performances. In my spare time, I love to visit Bethany Beach, Delaware, play the organ at my church, and watch â€œParks and Recreationâ€ with my closest friends.

#CSDimpact #BacktoCSD #ThisIsCheltenham #WildcatWay

post_text:
Dear Cheltenham Families and Staff â€“

The beginning of the 2020-21 school year is just a little more than two weeks away and my administrative team, principals and teachers have been busy preparing to ensure your children hit the ground running on Day One of virtual learning.

The district continues to receive a large number of questions regarding reopening, and we are grateful to the community for sharing our deep desire to make this coming school year as fruitful and healthy as possible. As part of our commitment to keeping you informed, please click through to review the second in a series of frequently asked questions (FAQs). We will continue to vet submitted questions and formulate additional FAQs on an ongoing basis.

Be well and stay safe.

Best,

Dr. Wagner Marseille
Superintendent of Schools

post_text: The Montco Office of Veterans Affairs is coordinating a drive-thru, first come, first served distribution of back-to-learning supplies for military and veteran families, which includes active duty, reserves and national guard. Evidence of veteran connection (veteran indication on driverâ€™s license, recorder of deeds veteran discount card, DD-214, or discharge certificate) and number of students is required. Families with a veteran connection include parents or grandparents. Register beforehand at http://ow.ly/1C6b50AZRGm. For questions, call Montco Veterans Affairs at 610-213-4022 or email Capplegate@montcopa.org.

post_text:
#STAYINFORMED
full report--> https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2355

August 2020 Facilities Committee Update

With co-chair Charles Burdell-Williams presiding, the Facilities Committee convened on Tuesday, Aug. 4 in a Zoom seminar room, which allowed the public to participate in real-time. The agenda included updates on COVID-19, facilities maintenance, capital projects for 2020-2021, facilities condition assessment report and SchoolDude. Committee members were briefed about the air conditioning project at Elkins Park, which is more than 50 percent completed, carpet replacement in Elkins Park classrooms, ADA upgrades at the high school and administration building and more. The facilities condition assessment has started for the district's remaining schools. The data will be collected and district is hopeful to present it at the October meeting. The next Facilities committee meeting is Tuesday, Sept. 1 at 7 p.m.

post_text:
Dr. Marseille issued a letter today outlining his 8/3 Fall reopening recommendation to the board ...

"....... After careful consideration, at the August 3 (cheltenham.org/zoom) special board meeting, I will recommend to our board of school directors a full virtual model for the fall semester for all students. My administration will continue to monitor this evolving situation with the possibility of reopening in the future under a hybrid (combination of in-person and virtual instruction) or full in-person model depending on the mitigation of COVID-19. What Iâ€™m putting forth to the board is but a recommendation and, ultimately, the board will discuss the recommendation publicly to determine whether to proceed with and/or make modifications to the plan."

Click through to read the entire letter>

post_text:
Committees on curriculum and instruction, health and wellness, operations, and student activities and sports have been created to analyze the pros, cons, and implications of scenarios under consideration to re-open schools in August and assist in the development of our health and safety plan. Committee membership comprises students and families, members of the Cheltenham Educatorsâ€™ Association (CEA), Business Employeesâ€™ Council (BEC), school board, and Cheltenham community, and school-level and central office administrators. These committees will meet once a week through the week of July 27:

Following every meeting, the subcommittees will share with the community written reports outlining how each of the aforementioned areas will be addressed. All school reopening information is available at cheltenham.org/road2reopening.

For those with questions, please send them to schoolreopeningcommittee@cheltenham.org. Questions will be routed to the appropriate sub-committee.

www.smore.com/tgu12

School Reopening Survey

Cheltenham School District
July 14 at 12:07 AM Â·

Dear Cheltenham School District Community,

As the school reopening committees continue to weigh the pros, cons and implications of scenarios under consideration to reopen schools and develop the district health and safety plan, you are invited to contribute your thoughts by completing this survey. A secondary student survey is forthcoming.

Through this survey, the committees intend to connect quantifiable data to the anecdotal data collected through the thoughtful questions, comments and concerns sent to schoolreopeningcommittee@cheltenham.org.

Please submit your completed survey by Thursday, July 16 at 8 p.m.

Administration will present the health and safety plan to the CSD Board of Directors on Monday, August 3.

Thank you in advance.

July 9, 2020

Dear Cheltenham High School Families,

First and foremost, we hope you and your loved ones are safe and healthy. The COVID-19 pandemic has been stressful to many and we recognize participation in athletics and marching band can be a healthy way to cope with stress and connect with our community. After careful thought and planning, we are excited to inform you the board of school directors approved the districtâ€™s Athletics and Marching Band Health and Safety Plan for voluntary workouts at Wednesday eveningâ€™s special board meeting. As a result, we will begin holding voluntary summer workouts, while adhering to CDC guidelines to
protect players, coaches, families, and community.

Click through to read more from Superintendent Dr. Wagner Marseille and Director of Athletics and Activities Suni K. Blackwell.

post_text:
Dear Cheltenham School District Families,

I hope this letter finds you doing well and remaining safe. As Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf moves Montgomery County into the â€œGreenâ€ phase, members of the districtâ€™s office of education and operations departments continue to meet weekly to collaborate and problem-solve, and review the most recent information from federal, state and local health agencies and the Pennsylvania Department of Education (PDE).

Just this week, PDE issued new guidance, in partnership with Regional Educational Laboratory (REL) Mid-Atlantic at Mathematica, one of the nationâ€™s foremost social policy research firms. The 60-page report is divided into three key parts: Emerging evidence on COVID-19 and school closures; key Informant interviews; and agent-based model predictions. The report attempts to help school districts make informed decisions in the development of their health and safety plans and opening procedures.

Click through for more on school reopening, equity policy and PIAA safety plan >>>>>>>

Educational Affairs Committee June 2020

With co-chair Tyrone Scott presiding, and co-chair Pam Henry, board members, administrators, teacher and community members in attendance, the Educational Affairs Committee convened in a Zoom seminar room on Tuesday, June 16. The agendaâ€™s lone item was the progress made during the fourth year of the strategic plan, Five Pathways, One Destination (cheltenham.org/strategicplan). Administrators from the offices of education and communications presented updates on the yearly milestones in each of the pathways: Curriculum and instruction, student achievement, professional learning, holistic experiences and communications and engagement. post_text:
The Cheltenham High School Jazz Big band has gone virtual! When the pandemic first took hold, many musicians speculated wildly about how the remainder of the season would look. It became clear quickly that the 2019-2020 season would abruptly come to a close leaving many â€” including our talented seniors â€” without a final send-off.

The CHSvJBB, however, did not take these challenges as defeats. Members proved their resiliency and came together to produce an incredible performance of one of this yearâ€™s selections.

We would like to wish everyone a safe and happy summer. To JBB seniors, congratulations and good luck with your future endeavors. We hope you take this with you as a memento to encapsulate this time in history. Please enjoy the Cheltenham High School Virtual Jazz Big Band and its rendition of â€œYou Make Me Feel So Young.â€

#CHSMusicalArts #CHSJazzBigBand #ThisIsCheltenham

06/12/2020

Dear Cheltenham Families and Staff,

We are in the final lap of the 2019-20 school year. Days were sprints and months marathons. These past few months have reminded me of a Walter D. Wintle quote my high school track coach Mrs. Mackey used to keep us motivated to hold strong and finish:

If you think you are beaten, you are;
If you think you dare not, you donâ€™t;
If youâ€™d like to win, but think you canâ€™t,
Itâ€™s almost a cinch you wonâ€™t.
If you think youâ€™ll lose, youâ€™re lost,
For out in the word we find
Success begins with a fellowâ€™s will,
Itâ€™s all in the state of mind.

Click through for more about end-of-year move up / promotion activities and Thursday's town hall from Superintendent Dr. Wagner Marseille.

post_text:
Cheltenham Seniors Take Final Trip Down Memory Lane at Senior Parade of Schools

Cheltenham High School seniors took one final trip down memory lane at the inaugural CHS Parade of Schools on Wednesday, June 10. With signs and noisemakers, teachers, staff and administrators packed the bus loops at all seven of CSDâ€™s schools to cheer on members of the Class of 2020 as they parade by in cars.

In their caps and gowns and waving â€œthank youâ€ and other signs, seniors started the parade at their elementary schools, then made their way through the township with stops at Elkins Park School, Cedarbrook Middle School and Cheltenham High School. The students were met with fanfare at each stop, including piano and vocal performances of their school songs at Cheltenham and Myers elementaries.

Due to coronavirus, the parade replaced the traditional â€œSenior Walkâ€ through the studentsâ€™ lower schools and offered teachers and students one final opportunity to say goodbye.

#SeniorParade #Classof2020 #ThisIsCheltenham

post_text:
Dear Cheltenham Families and Staff,

In the past few days, I found myself experiencing a profound sense of joy and pride. It is not because my heart has stopped mourning the lives that have been taken so brutally or my anger and sadness with regard to the injustice and racism in this country have completely subsided. The joy comes from watching the sense of accomplishment and unencumbered elation on the faces of our young graduates. As they walked across the stage in their caps, gowns, stoles and cords, wearing colorful outfits and fancy shoes and donning extravagant mortarboard decorations, my heart was overflowing with happiness. Though the number of family members in attendance was smaller than at a typical graduation, the love our families radiated is just as powerful. I am so proud of this class and their accomplishments, and eagerly await seeing more of them on the stage on Monday and Tuesday.

Read more from CSD Superintendent Dr. Wagner Marseille>>>>>>>

post_text:
#STAYINFORMED
Communications Committee May 2020 Update

With co-chair Joel Fishbein presiding and board members Charles Burdell-Williams and Tyrone Scott, superintendent Dr. Wagner Marseille and members of the administration in attendance, the communications committee convened a virtual meeting on Thursday, May 28. The agenda included the monthly communications analytics, social media year-end review and Coronavirus-related media relations. Thanks to spring sports senior salutes and other senior- and staff-related campaigns, Facebook metrics were up in most categories. The year-in-review included a platform-by-platform look at successful campaigns and cumulative statistics. Coronavirus-related media relations included a few trend articles in the Inquirer, a story about the new teacher contracts on Inquirer.com and some television hits focused on senior events. The Communications Committee will reconvene in August.

full report-->https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/3203

shared_text:
Cheltenham Township Police Dept., PA
June 1 at 11:22 PM Â·

To Our Residents.

We have received many emails and inquiries regarding all of the rioting and looting that has been happening all over our area. We share in your concern and frustration and have dealt with a number of incidents over the past few days. We have been closely monitoring all of the intelligence along with social media on a daily basis. We have ensured that we have all of the necessary resources to handle these incidents and have also worked closely with many of our law enforcement partners from all over the county. We urge our residents to remain calm and know that the Cheltenham Township Police Department has been working diligently and proactively to ensure the safety and well-being of all of our residents and businesses.

post_text:
STAY INFORMED

Due to the June 2 primary elections, the June Facilities and Finance Committee meetings have been postponed. The district will announce a new date once it has been selected.

On a related note, the Board of School Directors of the Cheltenham School District has scheduled a special board meeting to approve the final budget for the 2020-2021 school year on Tuesday, June 16 at 6:15 p.m. This meeting will occur immediately prior to the Educational Affairs Committee meeting.

The public is encouraged to join the meeting and ask questions through the Q&A interface at cheltenham.org/zoom. Meeting will also be available at Cheltenham.org/stream, Comcast Ch. 42 and Verizon Ch. 1960.

post_text:
Cheltenham Families and Staff,

Like so many of you, I have been searching for the words to describe my feelings in light of the protests and violence taking place and anger on display in more than two dozen cities across our country. I wanted to communicate with you much sooner, but I have been angry. So as part of my training, I am using the practice of the 3Ps and an A (Pause, Paraphrase, Probe and Acknowledge) of cultural proficiency. Iâ€™ve been engaged in deep reflection, knowing I should not react hastily when emotions overwhelm me.

Read more from CSD Superintendent Dr. Wagner Marseille>>>>>>

post_text:
CBK PBL Manual Cinema Documentary Features Student Voice

As part of his Avalon Foundation Design Fellowship, CBK project based learning teacher Isaac Stanford created a student voice-focused video highlighting the three core practices (collaboration, student choice and community partnerships) of the classâ€™ Manual Cinema project. In this project, students connected their previous assignment, the story map project, to creating cinematic shadow puppets. The goal was to create entertaining and informative movies to introduce their Cheltenham Elementary School â€œbuddiesâ€ to the places they researched in the story map project. Both videos will be featured on High Tech Highâ€™s UnBoxed website as part of its effort to showcase project based learning in public school classrooms.

#ProjectBasedLearning #ThisIsCheltenham

post_text:
This week, we honor our more than 40 spring sports senior student-athletes from baseball, softball, girls lacrosse, boys volleyball, and boys, girls and unified track and field. Their seasons may have been canceled but our love for them was not! Their years of training, dedication to achieving goals and sportsmanship will not soon be forgotten.

CHS Athletics hung these 40+ posters on the fence along Rices Mill Rd. in front of the high school for the entire community to see. If you have the opportunity, check them out.
#PantherPride #Classof2020

Their seasons may have been canceled but our love for them was not! Their years of training, dedication to achieving goals and sportsmanship will not soon be forgotten.

CHS Athletics hung these 40+ posters on the fence along Rices Mill Rd. in front of the high school for the entire community to see. If you have the opportunity, check them out.
#PantherPride #Classof2020

post_text:
Senior Awards Night

Join CHS Principal Dr. Renato Lajara as he and his staff honor Cheltenham's best of the best from the Class of 2020 at the annual senior awards night!

Monday, June 1 at 7:00 p.m.

Tune in on cheltenham.org/zoom.

The event will stream on cheltenham.org/stream and broadcast on Comcast Ch. 42 and Verizon Ch. 1960.
text:

post_text:
Spring Sports Student-Athletes Senior Salute

This week, we honor our more than 40 spring sports senior student-athletes from baseball, softball, girls lacrosse, boys volleyball, and boys, girls and unified track and field. Their seasons may have been canceled but our love for them was not! Their years of training, dedication to achieving goals and sportsmanship will not soon be forgotten.

post_text:
Dear Cheltenham Families and Staff,

I hope this communication finds you doing well and staying safe. Itâ€™s difficult to grasp that we are winding down this most â€œsurrealâ€ school year. While not without its challenges, distance learning has revealed a strong collective resolve, a bottomless well of grace, and a commitment to educating our youth among our families.

With June approaching, celebrations arenâ€™t far behind. Though unlike any end-of-year anyone has witnessed, this spring, we will stand for our elementary school fourth-graders heading to Elkins Park; EP sixth graders moving to Cedarbrook; CBK eighth graders being promoted to the high school, and CHS seniors poised to begin their next adventure. We will adjust and adapt and I canâ€™t wait to celebrate them all - just in new ways.

Click through to read more from Dr. Marseille, including information about reopening school in the fall, athletics, cap and gown pick up, and equity policy first read >>>>>

post_text:
Congratulations and Happy Retirement!!

Thank you and congratulations to David Wisch for his 22 years of service and dedication to the students of the Cheltenham School District. David may be retiring, but he won't soon be forgotten. He took this opportunity to provide us all one more lesson in his parting words...

"I am a Cheltenham graduate, a Cheltenham resident, a Cheltenham parent, and a Cheltenham teacher. Wherever life takes me next I will always be Blue & Gold at heart.

Thanks to all for giving my family the opportunity to thrive in this remarkable community. "

David Wisch
#ThisIsCheltenham #PantherPride

post_text:
On Tuesday, May 19, the Office of Education presented options for a new elementary reading series.

View here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1h4LvorOztVNflPcwrNQA6tITC5_5L6ra/view?usp=sharing

CSD needs a new primary English language arts resource to replace Storytown, which the district purchased in 2009. Storytown has been discontinued in print and electronic versions. E-resources are critical for fall 2020 and beyond.

A committee of teachers and administrators has narrowed the field to four finalists: Fountas and Pinnell Classroom, intoReading, myView Literacy, and Wonders. All elementary teachers and administrators have received a survey on the finalists' resources to share their feedback with the committee. A final decision on the Reading Program will be determined no later than June 1, 2020.

Please click through to review the options and send feedback to readingseriescomments@cheltenham.org.

post_text:
Wyncote Students Play Flipgrid â€œWould You Rather?â€

In an effort to give students a voice and chance to share their thoughts, Wyncote students have been encouraged to post on library media specialist Amy Flynnâ€™s â€œWe Are All in This Togetherâ€ Flipgrid page. Each week, Flynn posts a fun topic for students to share their opinions, ideas or knowledge. Topics have ranged from poems to â€œWould You Rather?â€ to â€œGuess My Spanish Word.â€ â€œWould You Ratherâ€ included tough choices like â€œfind a unicorn or a genie?â€ â€œbe a dancer or singer?â€ and â€œeat donuts or watermelon?â€

During distance learning, some students and teachers struggle with not feeling connected and being able to â€œseeâ€ each other. Videos are unique and provide students and teachers the chance to engage in two-way communication. Flipgrid is used for a variety of purposes but, one of the most important is amplifying student voice. Itâ€™s called #FlipgridFever. View â€œWould You Ratherâ€ Flipgrid> http://ow.ly/6Pyl50zA1mt

#WyncotePride #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham
text:
Wyncote Students Play Flipgrid â€œWould You Rather?â€

In an effort to give students a voice and chance to share their thoughts, Wyncote students have been encouraged to post on library media specialist Amy Flynnâ€™s â€œWe Are All in This Togetherâ€ Flipgrid page. Each week, Flynn posts a fun topic for students to share their opinions, ideas or knowledge. Topics have ranged from poems to â€œWould You Rather?â€ to â€œGuess My Spanish Word.â€ â€œWould You Ratherâ€ included tough choices like â€œfind a unicorn or a genie?â€ â€œbe a dancer or singer?â€ and â€œeat donuts or watermelon?â€

During distance learning, some students and teachers struggle with not feeling connected and being able to â€œseeâ€ each other. Videos are unique and provide students and teachers the chance to engage in two-way communication. Flipgrid is used for a variety of purposes but, one of the most important is amplifying student voice. Itâ€™s called #FlipgridFever. View â€œWould You Ratherâ€ Flipgrid> http://ow.ly/6Pyl50zA1mt

#WyncotePride #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham

post_text:
CBK Digital Media Students Explore Canva, Create Coronavirus Safety-Themed Social Media Posts

This past week, Cedarbrook students in Alissa Levinsonâ€™s Digital Media class utilized Canva, a graphic design platform allowing users to create social media graphics, presentations, posters and other visual content, to create coronavirus safety-themed social media posts.

After learning Canvaâ€™s basics the previous week, students were challenged to utilize its numerous design elements, such as templates, stock photos and backgrounds, lines, layers and transparency. Hashtags like â€œ#stopthespread,â€ â€œ#wearamask,â€ â€œ#homemademasksâ€ and â€œ#maskselfieâ€ and selfies were encouraged.

The final products were creative and varied, including infographics and checklists, animals wearing masks, gratitude for healthcare workers and social distancing tips. Once the projects were turned in, Levinson posted some of them to the CBK Facebook page.

Great job CBK soon-to-be graphic designers!
#CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham

Glensideâ€™s â€œPoem in Your Pocketâ€ Day

In celebration of â€œPoem in your Pocket Day,â€ Glenside students submitted videos via Flipgrid of themselves reading poems, some of them their own creation. â€œPoem in Your Pocket Dayâ€ takes place every year during National Poetry Month, and began in New York City in April 2002. In 2008, the Academy of American Poets took the initiative to all 50 United States, encouraging individuals around the country to participate. View the Mix Tape> http://ow.ly/9QZz50zxm2o

#GlensidePride #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham

post_text:
National Decision Day - Friday, May 1

In the midst of the chaos the coronavirus pandemic is causing, one thing remains certain. The Class of 2020 has plans â€¦ and we canâ€™t wait to find out what they are. Whether they plan to attend college, join the workforce, learn a trade, take a gap year or serve our country, National Decision Day on Friday, May 1 is CSDâ€™s opportunity to celebrate them and their future plans.

Since we wonâ€™t be able to celebrate at the high school by taking pictures of students wearing garb reflecting their choices, the counseling and communications offices are partnering to host a virtual National Decision Day.

Participating is simple. Take a high quality photo of your student wherein they announce their plans (even if itâ€™s just them holding a sheet of paper with their decision) and forward it, along with their name and decision to communications@cheltenham.org by Wednesday, April 29 at 5 p.m.

Questions can be addressed to Ms. Lori Cohen. (lcohen@cheltenham.org)
#PantherPride #DecisionDay2020

â€¢ Wyncote fourth grader spends shutdown in "A Galaxy Far, Far Away"

To update your contact information, visit www.cheltenham.org/updatemyinfo. Policy Committee Presentation April 2020
full presentation--> https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2657

The district hosted its April 22 Policy Committee meeting in a Zoom seminar room. Co-chairs Dan Schultz and Julie Haywood, committee members Joel Fishbein, Tyrone Scott and Charles Burdell-Williams, superintendent, administrators and solicitor were in attendance. The following items with their original year of adoption in parenthesis moved forward for action at the Tuesday, April 28 legislative board meeting:

Policy 115 Vocational Education (1999): Change to â€œCareer and Technical Educationâ€

Policy 213.1 Academic Failures and Make Up (1997): Repeal

Policy and AR 245 Student Identification Cards (2008): Adoption

Policy 706 Property Records (1998): Adoption

Policy 706.1 Disposal of District-Owned Books and Supplies (1999): Change to â€œDisposal of District-Owned Propertyâ€

Policy 706.2 Disposal of District-Owned Equipment (1999): Repeal

The next Policy Committee meeting will be held on Wednesday, May 27 at 8 a.m.

post_text:
Montgomery County Recruitment Outreach Virtual Education Career Fair

The Cheltenham School District is proud to participate in the Montgomery County Recruitment Outreach (MCRO) Virtual Education Career Fair on Thursday, May 7 from noon to 5 p.m. MCRO is a consortium of Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, public school districts dedicated to the recruitment, selection and employment of diverse, skilled, and talented educators. Candidates must pre-register by Monday, May 4 and will be scheduled a designated time to speak one-on-one with a representative. To pre-register, please visit www.mciu.org/MCRO.
Email MCRO@mciu.org with any questions.

April Facilities Committee Presentation
full presentation--> https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2355

With co-chair David Cohen presiding via Zoom, the Facilities Committee convened on Tuesday, April 14. The agenda included updates on COVID-19-related facilities and maintenance updates, facilities building updates, facilities condition assessment and project works. Committee members were briefed about the Elkins Park School air conditioning upgrades, which will include adding power to support installing window AC units throughout the building, and the need for this work to be approved to continue during the government-mandated COVID-19 school shutdown. The committee meets next on Tuesday, May 5, 2020.

#STAYINFORMED
April Facilities Committee Presentation
full presentation--> https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2355

With co-chair David Cohen presiding via Zoom, the Facilities Committee convened on Tuesday, April 14. The agenda included updates on COVID-19-related facilities and maintenance updates, facilities building updates, facilities condition assessment and project works. Committee members were briefed about the Elkins Park School air conditioning upgrades, which will include adding power to support installing window AC units throughout the building, and the need for this work to be approved to continue during the government-mandated COVID-19 school shutdown. The committee meets next on Tuesday, May 5, 2020.

post_text:
National Honor Society (NHS) 2020 Application Process

A student at CHS whose unweighted GPA is at least 3.4 is eligible to apply for membership in the NHS. If this applies to you, you can fill out the application on the NHS website at https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2652.

The applications will be due Monday, 11/2/20, and the induction of new members will take place in mid November. The following are required by the time you apply:

Â· a minimum of 20 service hours* by the time you apply
Â· signatures from coaches, club and volunteer sponsors
Â· one character form completed by a CHS staff member
Â· a character letter from an adult who is not a CHS employee
Â· a minimum of 20 hours in a school or community club, activity or
sport (one must be here at CHS)

*Service hours can include activities such as making masks, online tutoring, helping neighbors with their lawns, cleaning up litter at a local park, going to the supermarket for elderly neighbors, etc. For questions please contact Ms. Gloeckler, hgloeckler@cheltenham.org.
text:
National Honor Society (NHS) 2020 Application Process

A student at CHS whose unweighted GPA is at least 3.4 is eligible to apply for membership in the NHS. If this applies to you, you can fill out the application on the NHS website at https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2652.

The applications will be due Monday, 11/2/20, and the induction of new members will take place in mid November. The following are required by the time you apply:

Â· a minimum of 20 service hours* by the time you apply
Â· signatures from coaches, club and volunteer sponsors
Â· one character form completed by a CHS staff member
Â· a character letter from an adult who is not a CHS employee
Â· a minimum of 20 hours in a school or community club, activity or
sport (one must be here at CHS)

*Service hours can include activities such as making masks, online tutoring, helping neighbors with their lawns, cleaning up litter at a local park, going to the supermarket for elderly neighbors, etc. For questions please contact Ms. Gloeckler, hgloeckler@cheltenham.org.

Cheltenham School District

Cheltenham School District
April 2 at 1:39 PM Â·

The Cheltenham School District is committed to designing the most effective methods and systems available in the district for the continuation of our high-quality education despite the exceptional circumstances of the full school closure in the state of Pennsylvania. The purpose of this document is to outline how CSD will offer a Distance Learning model for the continuation of the educational program.

Distance learning for grades K-12 begins Monday, April 13!

post_text:
Cheltenham Families and Staff -

As you may have heard, this afternoon, Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf stated, â€œAll Pennsylvania schools will remain closed until further notice,â€ and extended the stay-at-home order through April 30. As the Pennsylvania Department of Education tweeted shortly after the announcement, â€œExtraordinary times call for extraordinary measures to protect everyoneâ€™s health and safety.â€

Nevertheless, learning must go on, and in these certainly extraordinary times, we appreciate your patience as our teachers undergo needed professional development to carry out meaningful and effective virtual learning with our students. Online schooling will begin following our April 6-10 spring break on April 13.

Click through to read the entire letter for updates on Tuesday's board meeting, grab-n-go meal distribution, technology for in-need K-4 families, facilities use, senior events and more>

post_text:
Update on Continuity of Education planning:

As we move toward our Continuity of Education plan, our teachers will spend the week of March 30 participating in several professional development workshops and planning for student learning experiences. Our staff will receive support in the areas of learning management platform, electronic communication systems, and other key areas critical to a quality distance learning program.

Staff and students will observe our Spring Break the week of April 6 with a return to instruction on April 13. We would love to be back in schools and engaged in person with our students by this time, but we are prepared to deliver a distance learning experience. Whether it is in a building or online, planned instruction facilitated by teachers will commence on April 13.

Click through to read the entire letter>>>>

post_text:
Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update No. 8

March 26, 2020

Dear Cheltenham Families and Staff -

Good evening. Though our schools remain closed as a result of COVID-19, our administrative team and staff have been conducting daily zoom meetings to discuss how to better support our students and families during this pandemic. These past two days, however, have been about whatâ€™s right in front of us, serving our most in-need families to do our part to ease their burdens.

For the second consecutive Wednesday, we distributed grab-n-go meal bags to our most in-need families. This week, we nearly topped 500 meal bags, all with enough food for several days. Our next meal bag distribution is on Wednesday, April 1 from 10 a.m. - noon at Administration Building (2000 Ashbourne Rd., Elkins Park).

To read the entire letter - including updates on continuity of education planning, winter and spring sports, advanced placement courses - please click through>>>>

Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update No. 8

March 26, 2020

Dear Cheltenham Families and Staff -

Good evening. Though our schools remain closed as a result of COVID-19, our administrative team and staff have been conducting daily zoom meetings to discuss how to better support our students and families during this pandemic. These past two days, however, have been about whatâ€™s right in front of us, serving our most in-need families to do our part to ease their burdens.

For the second consecutive Wednesday, we distributed grab-n-go meal bags to our most in-need families. This week, we nearly topped 500 meal bags, all with enough food for several days. Our next meal bag distribution is on Wednesday, April 1 from 10 a.m. - noon at Administration Building (2000 Ashbourne Rd., Elkins Park).

post_text: At Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf's 2 p.m. press conference today, he announced all Pennsylvania schools will be closed for two more weeks, and can reopen April 6. Since the district will be closed for spring break that week, the earliest students could be returning to school is the week of Monday, April 13. Gov. Wolf also issued a two-week stay-at-home order for six counties, including Montgomery County, starting Monday, March 23 at 8 p.m.
text: At Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf's 2 p.m. press conference today, he announced all Pennsylvania schools will be closed for two more weeks, and can reopen April 6. Since the district will be closed for spring break that week, the earliest students could be returning to school is the week of Monday, April 13. Gov. Wolf also issued a two-week stay-at-home order for six counties, including Montgomery County, starting Monday, March 23 at 8 p.m.

The Cheltenham School District has adopted the â€œSafe2Say Somethingâ€ (S2SS) anonymous reporting system for grades 7-12. District families from grades K-12 can use the system as well. Mandated under the Pennsylvania General Assemblyâ€™s 2018 Act 44, the program educates students and adults to recognize and report at-risk behavior â€“ especially on social media.
#Safe2SaySomething
text:
The Cheltenham School District has adopted the â€œSafe2Say Somethingâ€ (S2SS) anonymous reporting system for grades 7-12. District families from grades K-12 can use the system as well. Mandated under the Pennsylvania General Assemblyâ€™s 2018 Act 44, the program educates students and adults to recognize and report at-risk behavior â€“ especially on social media.

shared_text:
Andrea Merow is with Stuart Warsetsky and 3 others.
March 17 at 7:16 PM Â·

Volunteer Opportunity: We are grateful at Beth Sholom Elkins Park to be able to keep our food pantry open (a project with The Jewish Federation) to serve those in need in these uncertain times. The govt deems pantries as essential service. IF you are healthy, over age 21 and under age 60 we are looking for a few volunteers for specific times on Wed. Must be able to stand outside. Please msg me with your number and Iâ€™ll call you to see if we can have you help. And if not this week- we may need your help in the future. Thank you.

post_text:
Seniors of Cheltenham 2020

What challenges have you overcome?
â€œThe biggest challenge I've overcome is having problems with identity and self-esteem; realizing that I don't have anything to prove, and that the best I can do I'll do by being myself, was a critical moment for me. You don't have to be perfect, you don't even have to be good all of the time. Being honest about who you are as a person makes you a better person.â€
Laura Darling

Cheltenham School Districtâ€™s social media campaign #SeniorsOfCheltenham highlights seniors (nominated by their guidance counselors) who best represent the impact of a Cheltenham education through their dedication to scholarship, service, leadership and citizenship, as well as participation in school activities, clubs and athletics. The Cheltenham experience is unique and we are excited to share and celebrate all thatâ€™s great about Cheltenham through student voice.
#CSDimpact #PantherPride #ThisIsCheltenham

photo credit (Terron Gay, CHS '10)

post_text:
Seniors of Cheltenham 2020

What personal achievements make you most proud?
â€œI'm most proud of my art. Since childhood, and even the beginning of high school, I knew I loved creating art but my style was a bit undefined. Since getting to know myself and my taste better, I have a better sense of how I like to work and am much more confident in the work I put out. I'm proud that I was able to find my artistic style through trying new things and having new experiences. Life has informed my art more than anything else.â€
Laura Darling

post_text:
Seniors of Cheltenham 2020

What will you miss most about Cheltenham?
â€œThe thing I will miss most about Cheltenham is the community. I'm really at home here now, and I love this school. I'll miss just being here, seeing everyone, and participating in school events. Having to adapt to a new community of strangers will be a really big challenge, especially because of how comfortable I am now.â€
Laura Darling

post_text:
March 13, 2020

Dear Cheltenham School District Families -

The Cheltenham School District learned this afternoon from the Pennsylvania Department of Education (PDE) Secretary Pedro Rivera that schools will not be penalized if they fail to meet the annual day or hour requirements as the result of coronavirus-related closures.

To that end, during the next 14 days of the Pennsylvania Governor Wolf-imposed school shutdown, the Cheltenham School District will provide enrichment resources and activities to keep our K-12 students engaged. Students who do not complete these activities will not fall behind, nor will they be penalized. These resources are purely optional.

Click through to read the entire letter ...
shared_text:
DRIVE.GOOGLE.COM
academic enrichment.pdf
text:
March 13, 2020

Dear Cheltenham School District Families -

The Cheltenham School District learned this afternoon from the Pennsylvania Department of Education (PDE) Secretary Pedro Rivera that schools will not be penalized if they fail to meet the annual day or hour requirements as the result of coronavirus-related closures.

To that end, during the next 14 days of the Pennsylvania Governor Wolf-imposed school shutdown, the Cheltenham School District will provide enrichment resources and activities to keep our K-12 students engaged. Students who do not complete these activities will not fall behind, nor will they be penalized. These resources are purely optional.

Click through to read the entire letter ...

The Cheltenham School District has adopted the â€œSafe2Say Somethingâ€ (S2SS) anonymous reporting system for grades 7-12. District families from grades K-12 can use the system as well. Mandated under the Pennsylvania General Assemblyâ€™s 2018 Act 44, the program educates students and adults to recognize and report at-risk behavior â€“ especially on social media.
#Safe2SaySomething

post_text:
Cheltenham School District Hosts Reading Program Demonstration

The Cheltenham School District will host leading elementary reading series makers Wonders, Journeys, Fountas and Pinnell and myView for presentations and demonstrations Thursday, March 26 from 8 a.m. - 5 p.m. at the Administration Building (2000 Ashbourne Rd., Elkins Park, PA 19027). The companies were contacted based on the recommendations from the Curriculum Instruction & Professional Development Committee. Presentations and demonstrations are open to the public so please stop by to check out their offerings.

#csdReads #CSDimpact

Panthers first state tournament victory since defeating District 12's South Philadelphia High, 72-58, in the opening round of the 2006 tournament.

Next game is Wednesday. Time and location tbd.

Mandated under the Pennsylvania General Assemblyâ€™s 2018 Act 44, the program educates students and adults to recognize and report at-risk behavior â€“ especially on social media.

The Cheltenham Panthers (District 1 / No. 2 seed) take on the Easton Area High School (District 11 / No. 4 seed) Red Rovers in the first round of the PIAA 6A State Basketball tournament Saturday, March 7 at Council Rock South at 1 p.m.

Tickets are $8 for adults, $4 for students and are available during lunch through Friday, March 6. CSD is providing a FREE student bus for the ride to Council Rock South. Students must turn in a completed permission slip. http://ow.ly/6II550yE1lM

Alumni and fans should contact the CHS main office at 215-517-3700 to inquire about tickets.

post_text:
Junior Bass Qualifies for State Festival

Junior Caelan Donahue, a Bass 2 in Cheltenham High Schoolâ€™s Select Choir, was one of six in his voice category to qualify for the Pennsylvania All-State Festival at this past weekendâ€™s Pennsylvania Music Educators Association (PMEA) Region VI Chorus Festival at North Penn High School.

Representing Cheltenham well, Donahue performed with more than 150 other singers from across Bucks, Montgomery, Delaware, Chester and Philadelphia Counties during two days of rehearsals and an excellent concert.

The state festival is April 22-25 in Pocono Mountains, Pa., and Caelan and about 160 other exceptional young musicians from across the state will sing under the direction of Dr. Amanda Quist, the director of choral activities at the Frost School of Music at the University of Miami (Fla.).
#PantherPride #CSDimpact #CSDMusicalArts

post_text:
Best of luck to senior Isaiah Stehman (160 pounds) and junior Zachary Gaffin (182 pounds) as they take to the mat this weekend at the South East AAA Regional tournament at Souderton. After taking third at this past weekâ€™s District 1 AAA Section South, Stehman enters the tournament with a 31-2 record and faces Council Rock Northâ€™s senior Dillon Sheehy (33-4) in the preliminary round. Gaffin (26-7) finished fourth at this past weekâ€™s district tournament and faces the 182-pound class No. 1 seed, Spring-Ford junior Joey Milano (40-0), in the first round. Action starts at 5:30 p.m. Friday and 8:30 a.m. Saturday. Stehman and Gaffin are working hard to become the first Panther grapplers to qualify for states since sophomore 103-pounder Steve Gambino (30-9) in 2001. The top five wrestlers in each weight class qualify for the state tournament March 5-7 at the Giant Center in Hershey, Pa.
http://ow.ly/JnR250yyWoI

#PantherPride
text:
Best of luck to senior Isaiah Stehman (160 pounds) and junior Zachary Gaffin (182 pounds) as they take to the mat this weekend at the South East AAA Regional tournament at Souderton. After taking third at this past weekâ€™s District 1 AAA Section South, Stehman enters the tournament with a 31-2 record and faces Council Rock Northâ€™s senior Dillon Sheehy (33-4) in the preliminary round. Gaffin (26-7) finished fourth at this past weekâ€™s district tournament and faces the 182-pound class No. 1 seed, Spring-Ford junior Joey Milano (40-0), in the first round. Action starts at 5:30 p.m. Friday and 8:30 a.m. Saturday. Stehman and Gaffin are working hard to become the first Panther grapplers to qualify for states since sophomore 103-pounder Steve Gambino (30-9) in 2001. The top five wrestlers in each weight class qualify for the state tournament March 5-7 at the Giant Center in Hershey, Pa.
http://ow.ly/JnR250yyWoI

#PantherPride

post_text:
PBL Teachers Embedded at High Tech High

Through the school districtâ€™s partnership with the Avalon Foundation, a dozen teachers and administrators spent a week at worldâ€™s premier project based learning school, High Tech High in San Diego, Calif. The teachers spent the week embedded with a High Tech High teacher, learning and teaching side-by-side as a means to become well versed in the PBL instructional approach. The experience, which also included student-led tours, ideation workshop, overview of project work time and discussions on critique and revisions, will be followed up with a series of professional learning experiences with Cheltenhamâ€™s 20 other PBL teachers. With these efforts, the district will be able to offer PBL experiences to all secondary students starting in the 2020-2021 school year.
#csdSTEM #PBL #ProjectBasedLearning #ThisIsCheltenham

The No. 3-seeded Panthers (23-3) will face No. 7 seed Bensalem High School Tuesday, Feb. 25 at 6 p.m. at The Liacouras Center at Temple University in the semifinals of the District 1 tournament.

Check out the updated Hoops Central page for all the latest info. CHELTENHAM.ORG/HOOPSCENTRAL

Tickets are $10 and will be available to students and staff during lunch Monday and Tuesday, Feb. 24 and 25. Alumni and fans should contact the CHS main office at 215-517-3700 about purchasing tickets.

CSD is arranging for a bus to transport CHS students to the game for FREE. Students must turn in a completed permission slip (www.cheltenham.org/permissionslip).

Those driving to the game should mention "PIAA Basketball" for discounted parking ($14) at the Liacouras Center.

#GoPanthers #PantherPride
#Districts #beatBHS #TournamentTime

BOYS BASKETBALLCheltenham holds off Brickus, Coatesville to reach District 1-6A semifinalsby Mike Cabrey February 22, 2020

CHELTENHAM >> The Cheltenham boys basketball team held off a furious second-half comeback from Jhamir Brickus and Coatesville to earn its first trip to the District 1-6A semifinals in three seasons.

Brickus scored 23 of his game-high 30 points after halftime as the No. 6 seeded Red Raiders cut a 15-point deficit in the third down to one in the fourth but the No. 3 Panthers got just enough late baskets, stops and free throws to hold on and claim a 68-61 second round victory Friday night.

â€œWe just had to make sure we stayed focused,â€ Cheltenham senior Jaelen McGlone said.â€¦

CHELTENHAM >> The Cheltenham boys basketball team held off a furious second-half comeback from Jhamir Brickus and Coatesville to earn its first trip to the District 1-6A semifinals in three seasons.

Brickus scored 23 of his game-high 30 points after halftime as the No. 6 seeded Red Raiders cut a 15-point deficit in the third down to one in the fourth but the No. 3 Panthers got just enough late baskets, stops and free throws to hold on and claim a 68-61 second round victory Friday night.

â€œWe just had to make sure we stayed focused,â€ Cheltenham senior Jaelen McGlone said.â€¦

post_text:
World Day of Social Justice February 20, 2020

The United Nations General Assembly has recognized February 20 as World Day of Social Justice since 2008. In its declaration, the U.N. recognized social development and social justice as indispensable for the achievement and maintenance of peace and security within and among nations and that, in turn, social development and social justice cannot be attained in the absence of peace and security, or in the absence of respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms.

Some of the CHS Cultural Proficiency / Equity Student Ambassadors weighed in on what social justice is about to them.

"Walking in and out of classes with white people in cliques
Then walking up and down the street beside officers with clips...
Making me feel like Iâ€™m illegalâ€¦
Like I donâ€™t have the right to walk on the cement
But I should have to see men
Trying to unite my face with it.â€

David Cappel's poem "Nerf Guns"
CHS Sophomore

#WorldDayOfSocialJustice #WDSJ2020 #SocialJustice #Equity #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham

Senior Earns Photography Scholastic Art Honorable Mention Recognition

Senior Evie Gorman earned a 2020 Scholastic Art Awards honorable mention for her image of classmate Kyra Quigley. â€œScholastic Art recognition is a huge honor for our awardees and highlights the exceptional talent of our students,â€ said teacher Lori Oliveras.

The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards are the nationâ€™s longest-running and most prestigious recognition program for creative high school and middle school students. This year, students submitted nearly 350,000 works of visual art and writing to the Scholastic Awards, and more than 90,000 works were recognized at the regional level and celebrated in local exhibitions and ceremonies. Visual and literary arts luminaries serve as jurors. Some jurors are past award recipients. Panelists look for works that best exemplify originality, technical skill and the emergence of a personal voice or vision.â€
#PantherPride

post_text:
World Day of Social Justice February 20, 2020

The United Nations General Assembly has recognized February 20 as World Day of Social Justice since 2008. In its declaration, the U.N. recognized social development and social justice as indispensable for the achievement and maintenance of peace and security within and among nations and that, in turn, social development and social justice cannot be attained in the absence of peace and security, or in the absence of respect for all human rights and fundamental freedoms.

Some of the CHS Cultural Proficiency / Equity Student Ambassadors weighed in on what social justice is about to them.

â€œRegardless of differences, equality is imperative for a productive and meaningful society.â€

Makayla Weems
CHS Sophomore

#WorldDayOfSocialJustice #WDSJ2020 #SocialJustice #Equity #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham

post_text:
Boys Basketball

Friday Night Rim Rocker!

The No. 3 Cheltenham Panthers host the No. 6 Coatesville Red Raiders on Friday at 7 p.m. in the quarterfinals of the District 1 tournament.

Because of the anticipated crowd, the majority of the tickets will be presale. Tickets are $5 and are available for students, families and district staff during all lunch periods on Thursday and Friday, Feb. 20 and 21.

Limited tickets will be available for purchase at the door.

Get yours early and avoid the game night rush!
#LetsGoPanthers #PantherPride #CHSHoopsFamily #ThisIsCheltenham #GoHam

post_text:
Junior Kofman Takes a Pair of Bronze Medals at SOL Swim Championships

At this past weekendâ€™s Suburban One League American Conference Swimming Championships, junior Eli Kofman earned bronze medals in the 200IM (2:01.81) and 100 Breastroke (1:01.66). This season, Kofman broke a 20-year-old school record in the 100 Breastroke and was already qualified for the district meet this coming weekend and will be joined there by Darien Williams, who made the cut in the 200 Freestyle. While the boys team finished seventh with 173 points, the girls team scored 133 points to finish sixth, and sophomore Melena Walter sang the National Anthem! The District 1 Championship meet is Thursday and Friday, Feb. 27-28 at La Salle University.
#PantherPride #CSDimpact

In this week's edition of #ThisIsCheltenham

â€¢ CBK Principal Marcy Hockfield to retire in June
â€¢ EP Recognizes Black History Month with PTO-sponsored speaker assemblies
â€¢ Boosterthon Fun Run crosses finish line with record profit for Myers
â€¢ CHS Cultural Proficiency / Equity Student Ambassadors pinned in county wide Initiative kickoff
â€¢ APEX Leadership training at Wyncote.
â€¢ "In the News" features a story about the county wide Cultural Proficiency / Equity Student Ambassador program.
â€¢ "Need to Know Info" features calendar reminders, including the 20-21 academic calendar, PSSA testing dates, committee reports, high school athletics schedule, upcoming meetings and events and this week's flyers.

To update your contact information, visit www.cheltenham.org/updatemyinfo. For updates throughout the week, be sure to visit cheltenham.org or the Cheltenham School District Facebook, Twitter or Instagram pages (Each can be found at @CheltenhanSD). If you know someone who would like to receive the weekly news share, direct them to the eNEWS icon at cheltenham.org to register.

The Cheltenham High School Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) club had a busy #STEM filled weekend... #csdSTEM #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham
#Repost @chs.wise
ãƒ»ãƒ»ãƒ»
This weekend was really fun for WISE! We had two students from Drexel come in and talk to us about college, pursing STEM in college, and Drexel itself. It was very informative and our members enjoyed this meeting a lot! We will also have a guest speaker at our next meeting so keep an eye out.
Some of our WISE members also went to UPennâ€™s Femmehacks (an all women and non-binary hack-a-thon)! They had a great time and learned a lot while meeting college students and eating great food!

Match Day Faces On!

Come support senior Panthers grapplers (l to r) Ian Patterson (145, 152 lbs.), Jeffery Gaskin (220, 285 lbs.), Zachary Hoffman (138, 145 lbs.) and Isiah Stehman (160, 170 lbs.) at this eveningâ€™s Senior Night celebration. Seeking their first league win, the Panthers host the Upper Moreland Bears at 7 p.m. before wrapping up the regular season with a match at Church Farm School Thursday and the Unionville Duals Saturday. Postseason begins Friday, Feb. 21 at the District 1 AAA Section South tournament at Interboro High School in Prospect Park, Pa. #PantherPride

post_text:
#DidYouKnow?
With its 62-41 victory Friday at Hatboro-Horsham, the Panthers boys basketball team wrapped up the Suburban One League American Conference title for the first time in more than a decade.

With the hoops squadâ€™s fifth league title solidified, Cheltenham can claim American Conference titles in football and boys basketball in the same season for the first time in school history. With Ryan Nase at the helm, the football team won the conference title this fall with a perfect 6-0 mark, en route to playing in the state finals.

Adding intrigue to the Panthersâ€™ accomplishments is if the boys basketball team - led by second-year coach Pat Fleury - can win its final two regular season games this week, it will complete the season with a perfect 14-0 record, marking the first time in school history both teams will complete their league slates unblemished!

The Panthers wrap up the regular season with two games this week, home for Senior Night Tuesday versus Springfield and Thursday at Abington. Both games tip at 7 p.m.

post_text:
CSD PSSA Testing Dates

The annual Pennsylvania System School Assessment (PSSA) is a standards-based, criterion-referenced assessment providing students, parents, educators and citizens an understanding of student and school performance related to the attainment of proficiency of the academic standards. Every Pennsylvania student in grades 3 through 8 is assessed in English language arts (ELA) and math, and every Pennsylvania student in grades 4 and 8 is assessed in science. The standards identify what a student should know and be able to do at varying grade levels. Cheltenhamâ€™s PSSA dates are in late April and early May. Please see below for a schedule.

English Language Arts (Grades 3-8)
Tuesday, April 21 through Thursday, April 23

Math (Grades 3-8)
Monday, April 27 and Wednesday, April 29

Science (Grades 4 & 8)
Thursday, April 30 and Friday, May 1

post_text:
Board Bolsters Commitment to Equity with Daylong Retreat

The Cheltenham Board of School Directors spent this past Saturday strengthening their collective understanding of and commitment to cultural proficiency on retreat with diversity/cultural proficiency trainer Dr. Barbara Moore Williams. The group examined the cultural proficiency continuum and its essential elements, barriers and guiding principles. They took a spin on the social identity wheel, an exercise which encourages participants to identify and reflect on the various ways they identify socially, how those identities become visible or more keenly felt at different times, and how those identities impact the ways others perceive or treat them. They also spent time examining teacher and student identities. With the finalization of its equity statement and current work on an equity policy, the board exhibits tremendous support for cultural proficiency, equity, access and opportunity for all students.

#Equity #CulturalProficiency #Diversity #CSDimpact #ThisIsCheltenham

Cheltenham Police Take Wyncote Students on a â€œRead-Alongâ€

Cheltenham Township Police Department (CTPD) officers David Sparango and Don Baldwin stopped by Wyncote Thursday to read Kindness is Cooler, Mrs. Ruler to first graders. CTPD officers come to Wyncote monthly and read on a specific topic, which for January was â€œkindness.â€ In advance of National Kindness Day on February 18, families received paper hearts on which they are writing the studentsâ€™ random acts of kindness. The hearts will be sent back and hung in the hallway with the hope that a chain is completed by World Kindness Day.

#WorldKindnessDay #WyncotePride #ThisIsCheltenham
Cheltenham Township Police Dept., PA Cheltenham Township

post_text: #pbis
shared_text:
CSD Wyncote Elementary
January 24 at 1:52 AM Â·

Tonight Wyncote hosted PBIS Family Night. Families came to hear a presentation by Mr. Taylor about what PBIS is, what it will look like at Wyncote and how families can support at home. Students rotated around six stations. There was a leadership station hosted by APEX and a teamwork game in the gym. In the hallway, there was a fishing game where students had to fish for respectful behaviors. If the fished out a disrespectful fish it went into Re-teach Rapids. The final three stations were in the cafetorium. Families could create a home behavior matrix that uses the R.O.A.R. acronym, create hearts the highlighted ways to be kind, and play behavior bingo to learn about awesome actions and bummer behaviors. There was a photo op where families and friends could take a picture. Families had an exit ticket that said, "I can support PBIS by...." #wyncotepride #csdimpact #pbis

post_text:
#STAYINFORMED
Curriculum Night For 8th Through 11th Grade Families

Cheltenham High School's annual Curriculum Night is on Wednesday, January 22, 2020 at 6:30 p.m. Families should report to the Little Theatre (located in the back of the building, near the tennis courts) where you will receive a schedule to follow for the night.

An informational presentation regarding the course selection process will kickoff the evening followed by an opportunity for families to travel to classrooms, visit teachers and learn about course offerings.

We are excited to share with you a wide range of learning opportunities that will prepare your student(s) for college and career-readiness and we look forward to seeing you.

"Need to Know Info" features calendar reminders, committee report, high school athletics schedule, upcoming meetings and events and this week's flyers.

To update your contact information, visit www.cheltenham.org/updatemyinfo. For updates throughout the week, be sure to visit cheltenham.org or the Cheltenham School District Facebook, Twitter or Instagram pages. If you know someone who would like to receive the weekly news share, direct them to the eNEWS icon at cheltenham.org to register.

post_text:
PBL9 Publishes Literary Journal â€œThe Future through Our Eyesâ€

Project Based Learning freshmen have published the literary journal â€œThe Future through Our Eyes,â€ a collection of original student fiction, non-fiction and poetry now available on Amazon. Students selected one word they felt connected to their lives and wrote about the word and connection. Topics included everything from high school life to the world waiting beyond graduation.

Aside from literary work, students ran the entire process from editing, layout and cover design to the book launch party planning and promotion. The launch party is Thursday, Jan. 16 in the CHS Little Theatre and will feature music, food, readings, prizes, and a book signing by the authors. #PBL9 #ProjectBasedLearning #csdSTEM #ThisIsCheltenham

#STAYINFORMED
Full presentation:--> https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2355

With board member Charles Burdell-Wiliams presiding, the Facilities Committee convened on Tuesday, Jan. 7. Director of Facilities and Maintenance David Teasdale delivered project updates for the high school, Cedarbrook, Elkins Park, each elementary school and Administration Building. Committee members were briefed about the Elkins Park AC upgrades, which will include adding power to support installing window AC units throughout the building, and a more robust implementation of SchoolDude, a software suite for educational institutions which streamlines maintenance management, facility usage, technology management and energy management. The committee meets next on Tuesday, Feb. 4.
text:
#STAYINFORMED
Full presentation:--> https://www.cheltenham.org/Page/2355

With board member Charles Burdell-Wiliams presiding, the Facilities Committee convened on Tuesday, Jan. 7. Director of Facilities and Maintenance David Teasdale delivered project updates for the high school, Cedarbrook, Elkins Park, each elementary school and Administration Building. Committee members were briefed about the Elkins Park AC upgrades, which will include adding power to support installing window AC units throughout the building, and a more robust implementation of SchoolDude, a software suite for educational institutions which streamlines maintenance management, facility usage, technology management and energy management. The committee meets next on Tuesday, Feb. 4.

post_text:
CALLING ALL ABINGTON, CHELTENHAM AND JENKINTOWN TOWNSHIP BEGINNER AND EXPERIENCED LACROSSE PLAYERS

Registration for Abington Lacrosse Club (ALC) is happening NOW! (see flyer below). Evaluations for experienced players will be held on Sunday, Jan. 5 and 12 at Arcadia University's Bubble at the following times:

12:30 - 1:45 p.m. - C Division (3rd/4th Grade)
1:45 - 3 p.m. - B Division (5th/6th Grade)
3 - 4:15 p.m. - A Division (7th/8th Grade)

ALC plans multiple teams in each division, including an advanced team and beginner-level team. If your son would like to be considered for one of the advanced teams, he will need to attend both evaluation sessions.

Uniform samples will be provided at the evaluations so appropriate sizes can be determined. Families can order their uniforms (included in the registration fee) and other ALC gear through the organization's online store.

#Lax #FeederProgram

shared_text:
CSD Wyncote Elementary
January 3 at 1:02 AM Â·

As Wyncote enters the New Year, we started off on a new adventure. Today we explored the Wyncote Pride PBIS Safari. Each student received a passport to document their learning. As a class, the students travel to a new destination each day for a 20 min tour of that location with one of our guides. At the location, the explorers learn the behavior expectations for this area. Each expectation is stated in a kid-friendly and positive action phrase. Students are given chances to practice the expectations and then receive a "stamp" for the passport. We shared the new voice level posters as part of this lesson. We will be using this common language and expectations to reinforce positive behavior. We will continue this safari every morning this week and next. We will end with a bus lesson at the end of next week, Please ask your child what expectations they explore each day!
Thank you, Mr. Taylor (dismissal), Mrs. Scarpato (hallway), Mrs Keeley (playground), Mrs Krause (cafeteria) and Mrs Flynn (bathroom) for being our guides at each location. #wyncotepride #thisischeltenham

post_text:
Elkins Park Students Gift Holocaust Survivor Plaque in Honor of Deceased Siblings

Elkins Park teacher Lise Marlowe's sixth grade class presented 93-year-old Auschwitz survivor Itka Zygmontowicz a special plaque dedicated to the memory of her 11-year old brother Srulek and 13-year old sister, Syzl, who perished at the concentration camp on November 22, 1942.

The plaque is symbolic of Marloweâ€™s years-old stick figure collection representing those who perished at Aushwitz. Marlowe conceived of the stick figure project in 1996 as way to help students put into perspective the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust. The project is approaching 1.3 million stick figures, which represents only children nine and under, and covers the entire Elkins Park School gym. The class is determined to reach 1.5 million stick figures before Marlowe creates a stick figure exhibition at Gratz College in 2020.

Contact Lise Marlowe if you'd like to help her class finish the stick figure project. #NeverForget #ThisIsCheltenham

post_text:
Polar Panthers Take the Leap for Inclusion, Surpass Monetary Goal

Friday, Dec. 13, Polar Panthers from the high school took a long walk off a short platform into a freezing cold pool in support of CHS Unified Bocce and Track and Field at the annual Philadelphia Suburban Plunge at Souderton Area High School.

In all, more than two dozen Polar Panthers took the plunge, raising nearly $6,000, 170 percent of the team's fundraising goal. With the Plunge's overall top fundraiser, the Polar Panthers finished second among 11 teams in amount raised, second only to the host school.

Interim principal Dr. Renato Lajara jumped first, earning style points with a half twist, followed by a belly flop from football coach Ryan Nase. With the Panther rooting for them, a parade of student and teacher Polar Panther made the jump solo or with a friend or two. #ThisIsCheltenham #UnifiedSports

Click to view the team page and donate>https://www.classy.org/team/267656

Beat the rush at the gate on Friday evening and purchase your tickets for the Panthers' Class 5A football state championship game at 7 p.m. vs. Archbishop Wood Football.

Follow the link below to order your tickets, which you can print, show on your mobile phone or leave at will call to pick Friday at the Hersheypark Stadium box office.

Tickets are $8 for adults, $4 for students. Please note, ordering tickets online incurs a $1 service charge per ticket.

Once on the site, click "Find Tickets" and enter "Cheltenham" as the promo code.

post_text:
Select Choir Basses Make District Chorus Festival

At this past weekendâ€™s Pennsylvania Music Educators Association (PMEA) District 11 Chorus Festival auditions, CHS Select Choir members junior Caelan Donahue (Bass 2) and senior Roy Nussbaum (Bass 1) were selected to represent Cheltenham at the PMEA District Chorus Festival at Springfield Township High School in January. Donahue is making a return trip to the District Chorus Festival, while Nussbaum is making his first. The duo was chosen from a pool of nearly 350 singers from across Bucks and Montgomery Counties.

#PantherPride #PMEADistrict11
text:
Select Choir Basses Make District Chorus Festival

At this past weekendâ€™s Pennsylvania Music Educators Association (PMEA) District 11 Chorus Festival auditions, CHS Select Choir members junior Caelan Donahue (Bass 2) and senior Roy Nussbaum (Bass 1) were selected to represent Cheltenham at the PMEA District Chorus Festival at Springfield Township High School in January. Donahue is making a return trip to the District Chorus Festival, while Nussbaum is making his first. The duo was chosen from a pool of nearly 350 singers from across Bucks and Montgomery Counties.

#PantherPride #PMEADistrict11

post_text:
Panther alumni, parents and friends have all but filled a fan bus heading to Hershey, Pa., for the Panthers state semifinal game vs. Cocalico Friday at 6 p.m. at Hersheypark Stadium. The Cheltenham Panthers Football Parents Association wants to know if a second bus is needed.

Bus(es) will depart from the high school at 2 p.m. and make the 90-plus mile trip back to the high school immediately following the game. Pricing is in the works, but will not include tickets.

The high school is supplying a student bus separate of this effort. For more information, contact Daniel Gaffin at 267-242-6832.

As for senior QB Adonis Hunter (pictured), he's so excited, he already started running!

post_text:
Skills for Life Students Host Thanksgiving Feast

Against the backdrop of a YouTube video of a roaring fire, more than 20 CHS Skills for Life (S4L) students enjoyed the fruits (turkey rolls?) of their labor with students, teachers and administrators at their 10th annual Thanksgiving Feast.

â€œThis is one of my favorite days of the year,â€ said Skills for Life teacher Philip Cohen. â€œEveryone has such excitement and willingness to help in any way they can.â€

While balancing jobs and class, the S4L students cooked a tasty meal that included turkey rolls with stuffing, cranberry sauce, pineapple stuffing, macaroni and cheese, mashed potatoes, salad, cornbread and crescent rolls. They also outfitted their S4L suite in festive holiday decor. Many of the studentsâ€™ families provided the desserts.

The event is an excellent opportunity for the Skills for Life students to showcase the skills theyâ€™ve learned including shopping, budgeting and soft skills like entertaining guests.

#CSDimpact #thxgiving #grateful #gratitue #S4L #yum

post_text:
Grateful for our Community | Gratitude Tip #6

Take a Savoring Walk
Take a few minutes to take a walk outside by yourself or with your child(ren) every day for a week. As you walk, notice as many positive things around you like sights, sounds, smells, or other sensations. Look up, look down and all around. Listen...what do you hear? Smell...can you smell the weather? Acknowledge these things in your mindâ€”donâ€™t just let them slip past you. Pause to be sure your mind is registering all that it is experiencing.

Throughout the month of November we are sharing #Gratitude tips from our Positive Psychology Teacher Leader Team. Research shows that expressing gratitude increases your happiness by helping you notice the good things that are already happening.

post_text:
Grateful for our Community | Gratitude Tip #5

Gratitude Ping Pong
Find a partner... using a small ball, toss it back and forth to each other. Each time the ball is tossed the person tossing it says one thing they are grateful for. Keep track of the number of times the ball can be tossed without dropping it.

Throughout the month of November we are sharing #Gratitude tips from our Positive Psychology Teacher Leader Team. Research shows that expressing gratitude increases your happiness by helping you notice the good things that are already happening.

Grateful for our Community | Gratitude Tip #2

Create a Gratitude Stone
Paint a picture of something that is special to you on a stone. The stone can be large or small. If it is large, place it somewhere where you will see it daily or, if it is small, carry it in your pocket or purse as a quiet reminder of what you are grateful for.

Throughout the month of November we are sharing #Gratitude tips from our Positive Psychology Teacher Leader Team. Research shows that expressing gratitude increases your happiness by helping you notice the good things that are already happening.

post_text:
Panthers Perform at State Cross Country Championships

Two-time Suburban One American Conference Cross Country champion Janelle Williams competed in her third girls state championship this past Saturday and finished finished 52nd in a time of 19:49. Her time and place were her best efforts to date at the state meet. As a junior, she finished 54th in 20:38, and as a sophomore, she ran the course in 20:12 to come in 69th.

Competing in their first state meets, sophomore Zoe Matsinger completed Herseyâ€™s Parkview Course in 146th place (20:57), while senior Kylan Willis claimed 119th in the boys race (17:19.30) #PantherPride
